title: Amanda Luby
text:
I am an Assistant Professor of Statistics at Swarthmore College, on sabbatical for the 22/23 academic year. I primarily work on statistical methods for understanding complex decision-making, often using Bayesian tools. Right now, my work focuses on adapting and advocating for Item Response Theory-flavored models for forensic science, particularly in fingerprint analysis.
I’m also interested in statistics pedagogy, particularly in trying to better understand (and fix!) misconceptions among introductory students, and better integrating computing, applications, and theory in upper-level courses.
I’m currently seeking new collaborations in the social and criminal justice space. Please get in touch if you’d like to work together on a quantitative project in this realm.

title: Publications

title: Sigríður Björndotter
text: Sigríður Björndotter is a musician, vocalist, and live entertainment consultant living in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Her writing has appeared in Rolling Stone, Billboard, and NME, and she is a frequent contributor to National Public Radio’s All Songs Considered. She has been raising Pembroke Welsh Corgis since the age of six, and she has collected Casio watches since the age of ten.

title: Students
text:
My research group is located at Swarthmore College and focused on the measurement and analysis of forensic-decision-making processes. We primarily work with latent print examination applied to proficiency testing and the FBI “Black Box” and “White Box” studies.
Opportunities for current Swarthmore students include:
Interested students should contact me for further information. Desired prerequisites are Stat021 (Statistical Methods II) and Stat051 (Probability), but if you have some coding experience or are especially interested in forensics problems, please be in touch! Students willing to work with the team for multiple semesters will be given priority.
If you are a researcher at Swarthmore College or another institution looking to collaborate, please contact me

title: Students
text:
Highlights
Horace Shew ’22 received an honorable mention in the CMSAC Reproducible Research Competition (Methods-Student Track) for his paper “Applying Hierarchical Bayesian Models to ATP Data”.
Riley Thompson ’22 was a co-author on “Modeling Covarying Responses in Complex Tasks”, which was accepted for publication in Quantitative Psychology: The 86th Meeting of the Psychometric Society after completing the peer-review process.

title: Students
text:
Students








Horace Shew ’22
Horace is a Mathematics major with an Emphasis in Statistics along with a Classics minor. He focused on the implementation and comparison of various IRT models within a Bayesian and Frequentist framework in Summer 2021, and completed a project on modeling tennis outcomes with Bayesian hierarchical models during the 2021/2022 academic school year.



Riley Thompson ’22
Riley is a Mathematics major with an Emphasis in Statistics and a minor in Peace and Conflict Studies. Her research focused on covarying responses in IRT models and consistency of fingerprint examiner conclusions.



Thomas Daillak ’22
Thomas is an honors major in Mathematics and Economics. His research with the group focused on clustering methods for marked minutiae and IRT without an answer key.



Sherry Huang ’23
Sherry is a Mathematics major with an Emphasis in Statistics and Computer Science Minor. Sherry worked on a project on imputation bias in minutiae marking by fingerprint examiners, including building an interactive visualization app.



Alyssa Zhang ’24
Alyssa is a Mathematics and Computer Science double major. She worked on analyzing survey responses and demographic information of fingerprint examiners who participated in the FBI studies.
